Posts.Content: Cluster of microcalcifications on a mammogram is always suspicios. MRI or ultrasound guided core biopsy may be needed. Your MRI findings will help to make a decision. But do not worry, go step by step. As for your pain in the right arm, it seems unrelated to the lump and I guess, should settle down.

Posts.Title: 26 yr old with bad mammogram and ultrasound

Posts.Content: There is a lot of interest generated by cyberknife. Cyberknife and its related products are more for metastatic cancers than for treatment of any primary tumour. Like for example, a patient of breast cancer develops a secondary in the brain. Brain secondaries cause a lot of symptoms. And it is difficult to operate on same, especially if the tumour are multiple (where surgery is not possible, and conventional radiation therapy takes multiple sessions and results are not that good). With cyberknife, those secondaries can be targeted, with minimal loss of surrounding tissue, and render a patient symptom free. For the same brain mets, we would give palliative radiation therapy Cyberknife, as of now, is NOT indicated for primary surgery of breast at all. It is being tried in those areas where surgery is difficult, and for stage 4 disease, where surgery is to be avoided. As for your question on whether it helps and avoids complications of chemo, the answer is a strong NO. Because, cyberknife is only a 'local' therapy. It can never replace chemotherapy which is a 'systemic' therapy. The aim of chemotherapy is to destroy all cancer cells circulating in the system. The newer chemotherapy regimes have fewer side effects, and have excellent results.
Posts.Title: Its on Breast Cancer treatment ..

Posts.Content: Hi Mandy, From your description, it's difficult to comment on type of disease you may be having. If its very hard, and deep in tissue, and if you can feel, the rest of the breast is soft, they I am worried. Do consult your doctor as soon as possible. I would advise a mammogram (which is a special type of Xray of the breast), and an FNAC or core biopsy from the lesion (where they put in a needle, and get some tissue from the lesion and send to pathologist, for diagnosis). But before jumping onto conclusions, let your doc have a look. It may not be what we are suspecting.

Nothing stops me, I am going to live through all this, for my beloved!" We are all with you, Ladyblue.

Posts.Title: Invasive Lobular Carcinoma... I'm scared

Posts.Content: An uptake in PET scan most likely indicated recurrence of the disease process. Those liver lesions are likely to be 'metastatic' cancer nodules. Regarding the pelvic uptake, can you please write what exactly the report states. And how many various chemotherapy regimes has she undergone?
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer spread to liver

Posts.Content: The type of pain you describe is classically due to nerve irritation or stretching that occurs during axillary surgery. The nerve is called the 'intercostobrachial' nerve, and it supplies the skin on the inner side of arm, the side which touches the chest wall. After axillary surgery, it is common to have altered sensation on inner side of arm, sometimes it feels like pain, sometimes it feels like the arm feels 'heavy' etc. These tend to settle over a period of time. So do not worry, all will be fine, and your pain and other symptoms will definitely settle over a period of time.

Posts.Title: if you've had axillary lymph nodes removed, please read and advise!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gott April 5th, my breast started getting painful and sore. The next day I found a golf size ball lump in the same spot and in the same breast. April 7 the lump/mass got even bigger and turned in to an oblong shape about 3"x5". It is painful just like the one in Dec. The symptoms which you mention seem more in favour of an infective pathology and not a cancer. Besides, most breast cancers, rarely if ever, produce pain and redness (except inflammatory breast cancer). So I suggest, you visit your doctor and let him/her assess and opine.

Posts.Title: Triple Negative Breast Cancer (TNBC)

Posts.Content: FEMARA (Letrozole) does not increase the risk of endometrial cancer, Tamoxifen does. When you say, that the tests show signs of changes in the cells, what exactly is the report, could you be more elaborate on the words used in the report? (Does it mention 'dysplasia' or mention 'adenocarcinoma' or something like that). ANd like Didee said above, be careful while searching on the net, genuine sites are far and few. You could try the cancer.gov website, which has good info available. Besides, the best would be a detailed one to one session with your oncologist (not gynecologist), to solve your queries

Posts.Title: Risks of spreading?

Posts.Content: Hi Julie, Usually biopsy of the nodes is not needed, biopsy from the main lesion in the breast is all that is needed. Lymph nodes stuc together are called 'matted nodes'. If the lesion from the breast turns out to be a cancer; whether the nodes have cancer or not is not going to change management. If they are enlarged and clinically felt, a complete axillary clearance is done. So do not worry that your radiologist did not biopsy those nodes. Let the report of the biopsy from the lesion in the breast come and then it will be decision time.

Posts.Title: Supposed to biopsy Lymph Node, but didn't ??

Posts.Content: I understand the feelings you must be going through right now. When we are fighting cancer, there are times, when we just run out of available treatments, and just have to accept that we can fight it no longer. But we can definitely ensure, that whatever days our beloved has, we can make that special. Everything that she ever liked. Past family albums, reviving good old memories. Spending as much time with them as possible. Most important is that, I believe, the sufferer should know that time is limited (many may not agree with me, but I feel they should know), which initially will make the patient depressed, but within a few days, they accept it and face it bravely. The most important is to keep the patient symptom free. Brain tumours tend to have unacceptable symptoms, including convulsions, and they should be tackled aggressively. Hold your Dad's hand, and face it together. I always tell my patient, that about a 1 an 9 or 1 and 10 ladies are going to get breast cancer. Your are that 1 in 9, so it implies, you have saved the other 8 from getting breast cancer, and that's a noble job by all means. I hope you get the point.

Posts.Title: Unanswered confusion

Posts.Content: Breast cancer is one cancer where even in stage 4, we have treatment options available in the form of chemotherapy, hormonal therapy and targeted therapy (You can Google it for more details). Patients with spread to the bone only usually can survive for quite some time. But the moment, the cancer goes to other organs like liver, lungs, brain etc., the survival decreases. Nevertheless, if the sites of spread are limited, then chemotherapy may definitely be of benefit. When you say cancer in the 'stomach', I guess you mean 'abdomen'? Go ahead with treatment and pray. We all here pray for your mother. Most likely, your doctors will advise chemotherapy, as also radiation to the spine and one bone stabilizing injection called 'zoledronic acid' Let us know if you wish to know anything more or clear your doubts

Posts.Content: Axillary tail is a part of normal breast tissue. In some, it might be a little bulky, giving a feeling of a 'lump'. That is normal, and one does not need to operate for that. But get yourself checked, if there is any lump which has developed in that part or is it only bulky tail. A surgeon will be able to guide you.

Posts.Title: Lump found and ultrasound done...confused

Posts.Content: Hi Brandy, I will try to clarify a few things: 1. Since the nodes showed metastatic deposits, it is essential to do an axillary surgery to clear the axilla of all nodes. 2. Yours is a breast conservation surgery (lumpectomy). All patients who undergo lumpectomy also need radiation therpay, basically to decrease the chances of the cancer coming back in the same breast. 3. Any 'node positive cancer' needs chemotherapy 4. Depending on results of receptors, hormonal therapy will be planned. My advice: I can understand the anxiety you must be passing through, now. All of us are worried by the word 'chemotherapy'. We think of loss of hair, vomiting and other side effects. But believe me, the present molecules do not cause as much side effects as before ten years. And these side effects are easily controlled. So a few days after your every chemo cycle, you will be back to normal, do not worry. Radiation by itself, does not cause any pain or such. It is just cumbersome, to daily go and sit through the sessions. Think of your daughters, go to your doctor and tell him that I have to live for them, I am willing to fight, treat the way you have to. Time will fly, and soon you will be cancer free, dont worry. You might want to read up how we plan treatment here on my page: http://www.breastcancerindia.net/bc/bc/treatment.html
Posts.Signature: For a complete knowhow on breastcancer, visit: http://www.breastcancerindia.net Join the crusade against cancer, just say 'I CAN FIGHT IT'. http://facebook.com/icanfightit
Posts.Title: lost and confused

Posts.Content: Considering tumour size of 4.5 cm, radiation may be necessary (Usually we give radiation to anyone who has tumour more than 5 cm OR 4 or more positive lymph nodes). How many lymph nodes were positive? Anyways , I think in your case, the plan would be: adjuvant chemotherapy followed by adjuvant radiation (if necessary) and hormonal therapy which would be tamoxifen. Other hormonal agents do not function with a functioning ovary, so that cannot be given now. After 5 yrs of tamoxifen, if menopause occurs, you can switch over to Letrozole. HER2 is positive in your case. For that, targeted therapies like Herceptin also benefit.
Posts.Title: Need opinions on what type of treatment you think I may have to do

Posts.Content: Before starting Arimidex, we usually get a bone densitometry done. Arimidex and other similar medications have a very bad efffect on bones. That is why, along with Arimidex, I usually advice a calcium supplement at least once a day and a bone stabilizing drugs like Zoledronic Acid (given i.v, once in three months to once in six months, depending on patient to patient). Oral bone stabilizing agents are also available, like Osteofos (70mg) to be taken once a week, with a full glass of water, and upright posture for 30 minutes. You might want to discuss with your oncologist about them.

Posts.Title: Hysterectomy over Zoladex and Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: It is normal to have differing densities in the left and right breasts, nothing to worry about it at all. I would just advise to get yourself evaluated for that lump, since you say you can feel it, but the sonography doesn't show it. Sometimes, there is just a lumpish feel in the breast and no real lump. And even if it is lump, more than 90% of them, at this age group, are fibroadenomas, which are harmless. So it may be nothing, but to be safe, see a surgeon.
